# Task: Synthesize GitHub Copilot Content for Engineers

## Mission
**Help engineers stay current with GitHub Copilot through modular, topic-focused documentation.**

Engineers need:
- ‚úÖ **Modularity** - Each topic in its own file
- ‚úÖ **Scannability** - Quick navigation to relevant sections  
- ‚úÖ **Freshness** - Latest updates clearly separated from historical content
- ‚úÖ **Actionability** - Concrete examples and working links

---

## ‚ö†Ô∏è MANDATORY: Data Scraping Phase (ALWAYS REQUIRED FIRST)

**CRITICAL**: Before synthesizing any content, you **MUST** run the scrapers to fetch fresh data.

### Step 1: Install Dependencies
```bash
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

### Step 2: Run Scrapers (in order)
```bash
# 1. Fetch GitHub Copilot documentation (14+ files)
python3 scraper/fetch_docs.py

# 2. Fetch GitHub Blog posts (Copilot-related articles)
python3 scraper/fetch_blog.py

# 3. Detect changes since last update
python3 scraper/detect_changes.py
```

### Step 3: Verify Data
Before proceeding to content synthesis, verify:
- ‚úÖ `data/docs/` contains 14+ .md files (NOT just .gitkeep)
- ‚úÖ `data/metadata.json` is updated with latest timestamps
- ‚úÖ `data/changes-summary.json` shows detected changes

**If any of these checks fail, STOP and report the error. DO NOT proceed with content synthesis.**

### Why This Matters
- **Without fresh docs**: Content will be based on stale metadata only
- **Without blog posts**: Best practices and recent features will be missing
- **Without change detection**: WHATS-NEW.md will be inaccurate

**This scraping phase is NON-NEGOTIABLE. Always run it first.**

---

## Content Architecture: Modular Topic-Based Structure

We generate **8 focused content files** (+ 1 auto-generated), each serving a specific purpose:

```
content/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md          # Navigation hub (50-100 lines max)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ GETTING-STARTED.md # Quick start + best practices  
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ STARTER-KIT.md     # Deep onboarding: philosophy, workflow, training
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ WHATS-NEW.md       # Latest updates (last 30 days)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ VIDEOS.md          # Video library (AUTO-GENERATED by generate_videos.py)
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ TRAININGS.md       # Courses & certifications
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ CHANGELOG.md       # Complete historical timeline
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ COMMANDS.md        # Slash commands + shortcuts
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ REFERENCE.md       # Complete docs index
```

**Key Principles**: 
- Each file is **self-contained** and **topic-focused**. No mixing of concerns.
- **CRITICAL**: All content files use **UPPERCASE** naming (e.g., TRAININGS.md, not trainings.md)

---

## Data Sources
- `data/docs/` - Official GitHub documentation (14 Markdown files)
- `data/blog/` - GitHub Blog posts (JSON files with full HTML content)
- `data/videos/` - YouTube videos from GitHub channel (JSON files)
- `data/trainings/` - Training courses and certifications (JSON files)
- `data/changes-summary.json` - What changed since last scrape (with diff summaries)
- `data/metadata.json` - Version history and timestamps

---

## File 2: content/GETTING-STARTED.md - Quick Start + Best Practices

**Purpose**: Onboarding for new users + actionable best practices  
**Max Length**: 200-300 lines  
**Style**: Tutorial format with concrete examples

### Structure
```markdown
# Getting Started with GitHub Copilot

> Your 5-minute guide to productive AI pair programming

## üöÄ Quick Setup

### 1. Install Copilot in Your IDE

**VS Code**:
```bash
# Install extension
code --install-extension GitHub.copilot
```

**JetBrains**: Install from Plugins marketplace  
**Visual Studio**: Version 17.14+ includes built-in support  
**Xcode/Eclipse**: Available for Pro/Pro+ subscribers

### 2. Try Your First Prompt

Open any file and type a comment:
```javascript
// Create a function that validates email addresses with regex
```

Press `Enter` - Copilot suggests the implementation.

### 3. Use Chat for Complex Tasks

Press `Ctrl+I` (Windows/Linux) or `Cmd+I` (Mac):
```
Explain this codebase structure and list any failing tests
```

### 4. Enable Agent Mode (Optional)

For autonomous multi-step tasks:
- VS Code: Settings ‚Üí enable "Copilot > Agent Mode"
- Ask: "Add Redis caching to userSessionService with 30s TTL"
- Copilot determines files, makes changes, opens a PR

## üí° Best Practices

[Extract 5-7 actionable tips from recent blog posts]

### Write Context-Rich Prompts
‚ùå **Don't**: "Add caching"  
‚úÖ **Do**: "Add Redis caching to userSessionService with 30s TTL to reduce DB hits >1000/min"

‚Üí Source: [Blog post title](link)

[Continue with 4-6 more best practices]

## üéØ Next Steps

- **[Watch tutorials](VIDEOS.md)** - Learn from video demos
- **[Take courses](TRAININGS.md)** - Official GitHub Skills courses
- **[Explore updates](WHATS-NEW.md)** - See latest features

---

*For complete command reference, see [COMMANDS.md](COMMANDS.md)*
```

**AI Instructions**:
1. **Extract best practices from blog posts**:
   - Parse `data/blog/*.json` ‚Üí `content` field (HTML)
   - Look for: "best practice", "tip:", "prompt pattern:", "try this:", code examples
   - Extract 5-7 tips with concrete examples
   - Format: Title + ‚ùå/‚úÖ comparison or specific example + source link

2. **Quality checks**:
   - Each tip must be ACTIONABLE (engineer can try it immediately)
   - Include code examples or Do/Don't comparisons
   - Attribute source with link

# GitHub AI Starter Kit

## Welcome & Mission
[Brief introduction to mastering GitHub Copilot]

---

## 1. Understand the Landscape

### Two Modes, One Mission

**GitHub Copilot Agent Mode** (in your IDE)
- Your AI pair programmer
- Offers inline suggestions, code completions, and chat-based help
- Great for flow-state coding, refactoring, and exploration

**GitHub Copilot Coding Agent** (autonomous agent)
- Executes multi-step tasks using natural language instructions
- Operates on GitHub repos, reads `copilot-instructions.md`, and iterates
- Ideal for automation, scaffolding, and repetitive workflows

[Extract and link to latest blog posts about Agent Mode vs Coding Agent]

---

## 2. Best Practices

[Extract 5-8 key best practices from data/docs/copilot-best-practices.md and recent blog posts]

- Write clear, scoped instructions
- Start with small tasks, then iterate
- Use spec-driven development
- Use eval-driven development
- Keep context windows small
- [Add other relevant practices from docs]

[Link to official cheat sheets, guides, and resources]

---

## 3. Onboarding Your AI Peer Programmer

[Link to official getting started resources]
- [Get the Best Results](https://docs.github.com/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/copilot/tutorials/coding-agent/get-the-best-results)
- [GitHub Copilot Documentation](https://docs.github.com/en/copilot)

---

## 4. Agent Mode vs Coding Agent

| Feature        | Agent Mode (IDE)         | Coding Agent (GitHub)         |
|---------------|--------------------------|-------------------------------|
| Prompting     | Be specific, iterative   | Use structured markdown       |
| Context       | Keep files focused       | Use repo-wide context         |
| Validation    | Manual review            | Automated evals/tests         |
| Scope         | One function or file     | One task or workflow          |
| Feedback Loop | Accept/reject suggestions| Refine instructions iteratively|

**AI Instructions**:
1. **Extract from sources**:
   - `data/changes-summary.json` - Check `docs.changed` array

2. **Selection criteria**:
   - **Last 7 days**: TOP 3-5 most significant
   - **Last 30 days**: TOP 10 most significant
   - **Prioritize**: Blog posts about new features > Doc changes with `added_lines > 50` > Minor updates

3. **Keywords to look for**:
   - "new feature", "announcing", "now available", "introduces"
   - "coding agent", "mission control", "agent mode", "copilot cli"

4. **Auto-expiration**:
   - Items older than 30 days are NOT included here

## Slash Commands

Type `/` in the chat prompt box to see all available commands.

| Command | Description | Example |
|---------|-------------|---------|
| `/clear` | Clear the chat history | `/clear` |
| `/explain` | Explain selected code or concept | `/explain how async/await works` |
| `/fix` | Suggest fixes for problems in code | `/fix this bug` |
| `/generate` | Generate code based on requirements | `/generate a REST API endpoint` |
| `/help` | Get help using Copilot Chat | `/help` |
| `/optimize` | Analyze and improve code performance | `/optimize this function` |
| `/tests` | Generate unit tests | `/tests for authentication module` |
| `/doc` | Generate documentation | `/doc this API` |

[Extract complete list from data/docs/copilot-chat.md]

## Keyboard Shortcuts

### VS Code

| Action | Windows/Linux | Mac |
|--------|---------------|-----|
| Open chat view | `Ctrl+Alt+I` | `Cmd+Shift+I` |
| Quick chat | `Ctrl+Shift+Alt+L` | `Shift+Opt+Cmd+L` |
| Inline chat | `Ctrl+I` | `Cmd+I` |
| Accept suggestion | `Tab` | `Tab` |
| Dismiss suggestion | `Esc` | `Esc` |
| Show next suggestion | `Alt+]` | `Opt+]` |
| Show previous suggestion | `Alt+[` | `Opt+[` |

## Chat Variables

Type `#` in the chat prompt box to see available variables.

| Variable | Context | Example |
|----------|---------|---------|
| `#selection` | Currently selected code | `#selection explain this function` |
| `#file` | Current file | `#file add error handling` |
| `#editor` | Active editor content | `#editor refactor for readability` |
| `#web` | Web search results | `@github #web latest Python security best practices` |
| `#codebase` | Entire repository | `#codebase find all authentication logic` |

[Extract complete list from data/docs/copilot-chat.md]

---

## Chat Participants

Type `@` in the chat prompt box to see available participants.

| Participant | Expertise | When to Use |
|-------------|-----------|-------------|
| `@workspace` | Your codebase | Questions about your project structure, dependencies, or architecture |
| `@github` | GitHub-specific features | Repository operations, issues, pull requests, web search |
| `@terminal` | Command line | Shell commands, CLI tools, environment setup |
| `@vscode` | VS Code | Editor features, settings, extensions |

## AI Synthesis Guidelines

### Modularity is Key
- ‚ùå Don't: Mix topics in one file (e.g., videos + commands + changelog in README.md)
- ‚úÖ Do: Each topic gets its own file with clear boundaries

### Keep Navigation Simple
- ‚ùå Don't: Make users scroll through long README.md to find what they need
- ‚úÖ Do: README.md is a clean hub with links to topic-specific files

### Respect File Purposes
- README.md = Navigation hub (50-100 lines max)
- GETTING-STARTED.md = Tutorial + best practices (200-300 lines)
- STARTER-KIT.md = Deep onboarding guide (300-400 lines)
- WHATS-NEW.md = Recent updates only (auto-expires old content)
- VIDEOS.md = Auto-generated, DO NOT touch
- TRAININGS.md = Course catalog (400-500 lines)
- CHANGELOG.md = Complete history (unlimited, grows over time)
- COMMANDS.md = Quick reference tables (200-300 lines)
- REFERENCE.md = Doc index with links (100-200 lines)

### Quality Over Quantity
- Brief, actionable, with concrete examples
- Every item links to source
- No marketing fluff, assume technical audience

---

## Format Guidelines
- Use emojis sparingly but effectively (üì∞ üé• ‚ú® üìö)
- Keep content scannable with clear headers and lists
- Link to original sources
- Date all content updates
- Maintain consistent formatting across files

### Anchor Link Rules (CRITICAL - NEVER VIOLATE)

**GitHub strips emojis from anchor IDs. Anchor links with emojis WILL BREAK.**

**THE ONLY RULE: DO NOT USE EMOJIS IN SECTION HEADINGS THAT ARE LINK TARGETS**

**‚úÖ CORRECT - Clean headings without emojis:**
```markdown
## Official GitHub Courses
[Link to section](#official-github-courses)  <!-- ‚úÖ Works perfectly -->
```

**‚ùå WRONG - Emojis in headings that are link targets:**
```markdown
## üéì Official GitHub Courses  <!-- ‚ùå BROKEN - emoji in heading -->
[Link to section](#official-github-courses)  <!-- Link breaks because GitHub can't match -->
[Link to section](#üéì-official-github-courses)  <!-- Also broken -->
```

**How GitHub converts headings to anchors:**
1. Convert to lowercase
2. **Remove ALL emojis and special characters** (keep only: letters, numbers, spaces, hyphens, underscores)
3. Replace spaces with hyphens
4. Strip leading/trailing hyphens

**Exception: Navigation headers that are NOT link targets can use emojis:**
```markdown
## üìã Quick Navigation  <!-- ‚úÖ OK - No links point TO this heading -->
- [Official Courses](#official-github-courses)
- [Microsoft Learn](#microsoft-learn-modules)

## Official GitHub Courses  <!-- Clean heading - links point HERE -->
[content...]

## Microsoft Learn Modules  <!-- Clean heading - links point HERE -->
[content...]
```

**Validation (MANDATORY - Quality Gate):**
After generating or editing ANY content files, you MUST run link validation:

```bash
python3 scripts/validate_links.py
```

This script validates:
- ‚úÖ Internal file links work
- ‚úÖ Anchor links match actual headings
- ‚úÖ External URLs return HTTP 200
- ‚ö†Ô∏è  **Emojis in headings that are link targets** (CRITICAL RULE)

**The script MUST pass with zero errors before work is considered complete.**

If validation fails:
1. Fix all broken links immediately
2. Remove emojis from any headings that are link targets
3. Re-run validation until it passes
4. Verify links work on GitHub (not just VS Code preview)
